Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Dactyl-Manuform-R-T.title: Dactyl Manuform R-Track
Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Dactyl-Manuform-R-T.content:
Dactyl Manuform R-Track
Preface: This design is entirely made by QQurn, and details can be found at gitlab.com/keyboards1/dm_r_track.
After building my first ergonomic keyboard a few months prior, I wanted to do more electronics. I started toying with the idea of having a pointing device (something to move the mouse) integrated into the keyboard. In researching that idea, I stumbled upon an amazing design. Here are some of the key features:

Split Keyboard, 5x6 layout for 62 keys
PMW3360 Motion Sensor Integrated under the right thumb for Trackball
I^2C Communciation Between the Halves over RJ9
Arduino Micro on the Right, Pro Micro on the Left
Fully programmable with 32kB of flash

I was enthralled, but the only way to make one was with a 3D Printer. So I purchased a 3D Printer over the holidays, and got to work setting it up. After honing in the printer, I fired it up to create the case. But that was just the beginning of the work. The shape is molded to the human hand to minimize movement and maximize comfort, which requires a 3D “keywell,” curving the keys to the fingers. This shape prevents standard printed circuit boards, which are rigid and planar.
So, QQurn’s design resorts to “handwiring,” where the switches are connected by dozens of individual short wires soldered in air. To make matters worse, switch matrices require a diode on each key (see here for why). You have to solder each wire in air, totaling over 200 connections. It is very tedious.
So, painfully, over about 20 hours, I wired all the switches, along with an I^2C bus to communicate between the two microcontrollers, and the trackball sensor. A few hours of troubleshooting and a lot of firmware tweaking later, and I have an absolutely amazing keyboard. You really can’t understand how comfortable it is until you use it for a full work day, but it was definitely worth the time, money, and effort. Now for the fun part: Photos!


What Did I Learn?
While I didn’t create this design myself, there was still a lot of work involved in manufacturing and wiring it. I learned a ton about 3D printing, soldering, and also the QMK firmware framework which enables the keyboard to work.

Blog-Posts/Keyboards/ErgoTravel.title: ErgoTravel
Blog-Posts/Keyboards/ErgoTravel.content:
The ErgoTravel was my first foray into the world of Ergonomic Keyboards. For this first build, I stuck with something tried and true. I purchased a kit from an online retailer, and built it according to the instructions. While the components were all included, I had to solder everything by hand, my first major experience with soldering. It was a lot of fun.
Once I had everything soldered and assembled, the next step was firmware. The keyboard runs QMK, a C-based firmware framework that runs on hundreds of keyboard designs, including the ErgoTravel. The main config, describing the electrical design, was already complete, but I had to create and tweak my own keymap. The keymap determines what pressing a given key actually does. I decided to get ambitious and try out as many of QMKs features as possible, including tap dances, layers, layer-taps, and leader key. It was great to explore the firmware and learn a bit of C.
Once I had built the keyboard and been using it for a few weeks, a small problem became apparent: the kit didn’t come with a full case, so the PCB was partially exposed. I was slowly noticing dust and gunk accumulating, which I thought could become an issue long term. So I wanted to create a more full enclosure. Luckily, my father is a hobbyist wood-worker, so we worked together create a case of walnut. It’s beautiful, I think.

Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Icarus.title: Icarus
Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Icarus.content:
Icarus
Introduction
I had just finished a written math assignment when I thought to myself: why should I have to compute something on my calculator, then enter it into the computer? Why isn’t the calculator directly connected to my computer? So I decided to try and solve that problem by making a numpad and calculator in one. You activate calculate mode, input your calculation, and it writes out the answer. Here’s a quick feature overview:

Fully Programmable with QMK firmware
Custom PCB with onboard Cortex M4 Microprocessor
Integrated 128x32 OLED
USB-C Connection
4x5 Mechanical Key Matrix for 20 Keys

The project has two main parts: Hardware (PCB and case) and software (actual functionality).
Hardware Development
Circuitry
The microprocessor (i.e. the brain) is integrated directly into a custom PCB, along with USB circuitry, the key matrix, and a voltage regulator. The MCU runs on an external 16MHz crystal. I designed the PCB using KiCad, a free and open source CAD suite for electrical engineering. PCB development is one of my favorite parts of these keyboard projects, because its the right mix of creativity, problem solving, and research. For this board in particular I spent a lot of time reading about the STM32F4xx series and the best design practices for PCBs. Here’s the final schematic:

And the PCB Layout:

I had the PCB manufactured and some of the surface mount soldering done by JLCPCB.
Case Design
Once I had a designed the PCB, I needed somewhere to put it. A few months prior I had purchased a 3D printer, so I decided to design and 3D print a case. I created the enclosure in AutoDesk Fusion 360. I tried my hand at creating a screw-less design. The stackup involves three parts:

The main plate
The PCB
The bottom plate

The PCB is attached to the main plate by the tension between the mechanical switches (which snap into the plate) and the holes in the PCB. The bottom plate then has a “snap-fit” to attach to the main plate, fulling enclosing the PCB. Overall, I think it was pretty successful.
Software Development
This ended up being where the bulk of my time on this project went. It turns out that programming a calculator isn’t as easy as I thought! It turned out to be a great learning experience. At the start of this project I didn’t really have much experience with C programming, but I developed a lot of skills by programming Icarus. The base for the firmware is the wonderful Quantum Mechanical Keyboard Firmware, or QMK. It has a lot of abstraction that makes it easy to get started with your own firmware. Each keyboard has a config that defines its electrical configuration and layout, and then each user can create their own keymaps, with a specific layout to fit them. I assumed that setting up the initial config would be the easy part (as it had been with my previous boards), but I was quickly proved wrong. The first time I plugged in the PCB and flashed it with firmware that I thought was correct, the entire thing hung and became non-responsive. I spent hours debugging before eventually discovering that the quartz clock that I had chosen for the microcontroller was not the same speed as the QMK default. Once I fixed that, it was on to programming the calculator functionality.
While most normal inputs are easy to setup in QMK, I had to program the calculator functionality mostly from scratch. The way I tackled this was to create a togglable layer with custom defined keycodes corresponding to each matrix position. In other words, I defined functions for each key. Most of these functions write to a char array representing the current equation. The ”=” button then calls a function from the TinyExpr library to interpret that buffer into a numeric result, if possible. Pressing enter then sends it to the computer using the qmk “send_string()” function.
To make this all more user-friendly, I added a little 128x32 OLED that displays the current expression buffer and expected result as you enter in characters. On the default layer, where you just enter numbers like a numpad, it displays the layout because my keycaps are blank.
Final Product

Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Silvis.title: Silvis
Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Silvis.content:
Introduction
After building Tantalus and another Dactyl Manuform 5x6, I still wasn’t fully satisfied with my secondary keyboard. My Dactyl Manuform R-Track is perfect for my primary setup, but I have been moving around more and doing school work on a laptop. Unfortunately the Dactyl is quite bulky and a little finicky (owing to my amateur soldering job), so it isn’t very mobile.
I began toying around with ideas for a while. I finally settled on creating another flat keyboard. There would be no mousing device, no curved keywells. I wanted to prioritize the typing experience, above other luxuries. I figure it is better to make the best portable keyboard possible than a mediocre mouse and mediocre keyboard. So from that came Silvis.
Feature List

Custom PCB with On-board STM32F411 microcontroller
3D Printed Case designed in Fusion 360
Programmable with QMK
Addressable Per-Key RGB
USB-C
Hotswappable Cherry MX keys

Hardware Development
PCB
I designed the Silvis PCB using the KiCad suite, which I’m now pretty adept with. The PCB features an STM32F411 microcontroller, which has 512 Kb of flash and 128 Kb of ram, plenty for a keyboard. The schematic is overall similar to one of my previous projects, Icarus, because I chose the same MCU for both. The biggest difference is that Silvis features per-key SK6812 Mini-E LEDs, which are reversed mounted. This means that you solder them on the back, but they point up through a hole illuminating the keys from below.
Laying out the components for this PCB proved far more challenging then any of my previous designs. I wanted the design to be symmetric but unibody, with a couple of different angles between columns to match the splay of my hand. Additionally, each and every one of the 58 keys has both an LED and a diode (see here for why) attached to it. Placing that all by hand was… daunting. I knew I would make a mistake. So I started looking into ways to do it programmatically instead.
ErgoGen
Ergogen, short for ergonomic keyboard generator, is a Javascript project that allows you to describe a 2D keyboard layout using a YAML config, and then generate design files, including plate SVGs, PCBs, and even cases, from there. This allows for a much faster workflow, by tweaking code instead of manually shifting keys in KiCad. I used ErgoGen to place the switches, diodes, and LEDs for the Silvis matrix. I’m a huge fan of this project, and strongly suggest it to anyone looking to make their own ergonomic keyboard.
Case Design
I wanted Silvis to be able to hold up to abuse. I wanted a rigid case with a durable design. Of course, for those purposes, a 3D printed case probably wasn’t my best choice, but its what I had to work with.
The overall design is pretty simple. I have a 3d-printed shell that the PCB drops down into, then a FR4 plate goes over that, with 10 M3 screws holding everything together. I designed all of this in Fusion360.
Software Development
Software for this project was really easy. Over my past keyboard projects I have developed a strong understanding of QMK, so that is what I chose to use again. The only tricky part was configuring the LEDs to work properly.
Usage
I’ve now been using Silvis as my daily driver for about 6 months, and it is wonderful. All of my tedious design work really did pay off.

Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Tantalus.title: Tantalus
Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Tantalus.content:
Tantalus
Introduction
This is my 3rd ergonomic keyboard, and my first completely custom design. My previous build, the Dactyl Manuform R-Track, was almost perfect. However I needed another board for my second setup, and really didn’t want to handwire again. So, I set about learning how to design my own 3d models and create my own PCBs. I had a couple goals in mind:

Fully Programmable with QMK
38 Choc Keys with a layout optimized for prose
Custom PCB with integrated MCU
USB-C Connection
Trackball on a daughterboard

I achieved most of these goals, but in practice it isn’t perfect.
Hardware Development
This project was a great learning experience for a number of reasons, but the big one is that I got very acquainted with KiCad, an open source PCB design tool. From scratch, I learned how to create schematics, modify and design footprints, layout a PCB, route a PCB, and read datasheets. Since this was my first design, I kept it somewhat simple. No LEDs, no OLED, no split board, none of the other possible bells and whistles for QMK boards.
Instead of using a separate daughterboard for the microcontroller as I had on my previous two builds, Tantalus has an ATMEGA32U4 directly on the PCB, along with all of the clock and voltage regulating circuity that entails. This enables me to have a USB-C connection anywhere else on the PCB.
And the PCB Layout:

Once I finished the PCB, I set to work learning another tool from the ground up: AutoDesk Fusion 360. I needed to create a 3d printable enclosure for the PCB, with a spot for the trackball. I severely underestimated how hard it’d be. After many, many iterations, here is a render of the final design:

Assembly
I had the PCB manufactured and partially soldered by JLCPCB. Once I had soldered the rest of the components and printed the case, it came time to assemble everything. Unfortunately, everything didn’t go to plan. Some of the tolerances on the case were bad, the wiring was tight, and the trackball sensor interefered with the case closing. Additionally, I made a couple small mistakes on the PCB that rendered two keys non-functional, until I ran jumper wires to fix it. However, with a bit of gumption and a dremel, I was eventually able to get everything fitting and the case to close.
Final Product
Without further adue, here is how it turned out:

And the internals:

Is it janky? Yes. Did I make mistakes? Yes. Am I happy with the final product? Not really. Am I glad I did it? Absolutely. This was a great learning experience.

Blog-Posts/Posts/BWSI.title: Beaver Works Summer Institute
Blog-Posts/Posts/BWSI.content:
Beaver Works Summer Institute
Introduction
In the summer of 2023, I had the pleasure of attending the Beaver Works Summer Institute, a program for rising high school seniors run by MIT. It offers the brightest students in the nation the chance to work on fascinating engineering projects with courses taught by MIT faculty.
I chose to take the Autonomous Underwater Vehicle Challenge, where we learned to take a remotely operated underwater robot and transform it into something fully autonomous using sensor data, computer vision, and motor control. Here is what our robot looked like:

Physics
The first step on our journey to autonomy was understanding how the robot moves in the water. It has a 6 thruster configuration, with 4 on the xy plane and 2 for vertical movement. This allows us full control in all 3 dimensions. You can turn the robot (yaw) by turning on opposing horizontal thrusters. We didn’t really bother with pitch and roll, but you should be able to control those to. In order to understand how the robot actually moves, you have to do just a little bit of linear algebra. Thinking only in the 2D plane, you can find the horizontal and vertical components of each thruster using basic trigonometry. You can do the same to calculate torque, assuming you know the dimensions of the robot. Once you have the components relative to the AUV, you can translate them into the global plane using a rotation matrix. Now that calculation only gives us the acceleration of the AUV. You really want the expected position, so you have to integrate twice. This math formed the basis of our first week of study.
Motor Control
Now that we had an idea as to how the robot would respond, it was time to learn how to actually control it. We did so using the PID control model, which relies on an error and the change in that error over time in order to calculate how much to change by. Essentially, the speed of the motors depends on how far away from your target you are, and how quickly that distance is changing. This prevents you from overshooting. The code for this is actually exceedingly simple, but the bulk of the work came from testing it on our actual robots and honing in on the gain values.
Computer Vision
Okay, so we can control our robot and make it go where we want to now. How do we know, autonomously, where to go? The same way you do: with vision! Our robot is equipped with a high resolution, high refresh rate camera. You can process that image to gather data about the surroundings, and then decide where to go accordingly. For us, we had to main modes of travel: following April Tags (basically QR codes for robots), or following the lane of a pool. April tags stand out quite a bit an image, so they are pretty easy to find and follow. They give a lot of information based on their size in the image, so you can actually follow them pretty accurately. Pool lanes are a lot harder. They are just dark edges at the bottom of the pool, and there is often times multiple of them in the image, so it can be very difficult to detect them all and pick the right one. I would say that this problem is where the bulk of my development work went throughout the 4 week program.

Blog-Posts/Posts/Biking.title: Biking
Blog-Posts/Posts/Biking.content:
Biking
Research
As winter settled in and I began to spend more time inside, I was looking to get into a new excerise hobby. I spent a while thinking about it, and eventually decided that I wanted to start biking. I’ve known how to ride a bike for a long time, but I’ve never really had a good one, and never really gone on wrong rides. But after discovering the world of bikepacking and seeing all kinds of adventures documented on YouTube, I decided I was going to get into it. So, I spent about a month looking into all kinds of bikes, from sleek and modern road bikes to full-suspension mountain bikes. I learned a lot from that research. For one, bikes are expensive. There are also a lot of options. There’s suspension, drive trains, rim versus disc brakes, dropbar versus flatbar, and countless other of decisions to make before purchasing a bike. But, eventually, I started to develop an idea of what I wanted.
The Poseidon X
The bike I settled on, and purchased in December 2022, is the Poseidon X. It is a gravel bike, built for rougher terrain (like on gravel roads!) but not neccarisly bumpy and steep trails like you might tackle on a mountain bike. This seems like a good compromise for me, because I will be doing likely 80-90% of my riding on roads, even if I am excited to get on trails come summer. It is a rigid bike, meaning no front or rear suspension. This makes it easier to maintain and cheaper to purchase. It has a 1x10 cassette, which still offers plenty of range for tackling hills or going downhill.
As of January, I haven’t been able to go on any long rides yet due to cold weather. But, from the ~10 mile days I have done, the bike is excellent! Its a blast to ride, with smooth gear shifting, lots of braking power, and good ergonomics. I’m really happy with it!

Blog-Posts/Posts/Obsidian.title: Obsidian Notes
Blog-Posts/Posts/Obsidian.content:
Obsidian Notes
What is Obsidian?
In late 2022, I was lucky enough to stumble onto a wonderful project called Obsidian Notes. The principle is simple: a note-taking software composed of plain markdown files with a focus on interconnection and extensibility. You create a folder of markdown files, and use local links, tags, and canvases to connect everything. This allows you to move from file to file as you would thought to thought. It sounds simple, but is extremely powerful in practice.
But… why?
I was skeptical at first too. People online speak of note software like Obsidian as if they will completly change your life, and I didn’t believe them. But, now that I have been using Obsidian for about 3 months, it really does have a big impact on my workflow and thought proccesses. Essentially, whenever I learn a new concept or have an interesting thought I expect to revisit, I write it down in my Obsidian vault, often in shorthand at first. Then, when I have time later, I can expand it fully. Next time I think about that thing, I can just look at my note to refresh my memory. This can also serve as a to-do list; when you think of something you need to do, just write it down. Maybe tag it. Then you come back later. It has a huge impact on my ability to get things done. Fleeting thoughts become reality a lot more now that I use Obsidian.
Daily Notes
The very first place I write down most of these notes and thoughts is my daily note. A daily note is simply a file that you create each day with the date. From my daily notes I can get to everything I worked or thought about that day. In Obsidian, if you want to create a new file, you just write [[$file_name$]], and then hit Ctrl+Enter. This file will then have a “backlink” to your daily note, which can later be viewed graphically. This allows you to visualize ideas and thoughts on a graph, and follow your train of thoughts. This is especially powerful when you return to a project or idea after a long time.
Tags
Another hugely important feature of Obsidian is tags. I use tags just as topics. So if I make a file about a physics topic, I just tag it with physics. This can be done in two ways:

Inline tags
YAML Frontmatter

Inline tags are just written like#topic directly in your markdown. These are fast to make, but produce visual clutter. YAML Frontmatter tags are written at the very top of the file, like this:
---
tags: [xxxxx, yyyyy]
---

Both methods work with the other, so you can use whatever you want depending on the note. I tend to use inline tags in my daily notes, but YAML frontmatter for when I extract something to its own file.
Graph View
I mentioned the graph view, but I just wanted to give you a visual of what that looks like:

That is a screenshot of my main Obsidian vault, with over 500 notes. It gives a clear visual of how ideas and tags are related. Most of the grouping comes from tags, but those can be disabled to get a direct view of file-to-file connections, if that is what you are looking for. Its really interesting to visualize what you have learned and thought about for the past months.
Syncing
A conventional note-taking approach would involve a notebook, that you can take around with you and write things down in. Obsidian is digital, and not even natively in the cloud. So what do I do if I’m out and about and want to write something down? Well, the way I see it, there are two options:

Sync your vault across devices
Take intermediary notes on another device

I use a mix of both. Sometimes I will write things down on scraps of paper and fold them up in my pocket. Other times, I will write them using Obsidian for my phone (yes, its cross platform!).
There are a couple ways to sync a vault from your phone to laptop or similar. Obsidian themselves offer a service called Obsidian Sync, which is $10 a month for cross-platform cloud syncing with version history. A free approach is to setup a Git/GitHub repository, using the obsidian-git plugin.
Conclusion
So, I implore you: take a look at Obsidian. It might not be for you, and that’s fine, but if you have ever wanted to try out a note taking software, I truly believe that Obsidian is the best option available.

Concepts/Concepts.title: Concepts
Concepts/Concepts.content:
Topic: Psychology
Concepts
Concepts are ideas, rules, or mental groupings of similar objects, events, people, and activities. You have a concept of a ball that includes footballs, rubber balls, soccer balls, and cannon balls, for example. Concepts are typically based on prototypes.
Concepts can be loosely defined, such as a bird; this is a superordinate concept. They could also be very specific, which is called a subordinate concept, for example a Orange-breasted bunting.
This folder includes notes on a variety of concepts from a range of fields and across the subordinate to superordinate spectrum.

References
Myers Psychology for the AP Course; Module 34

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Electrical Conductors
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Topic: Electromagnetism
Electrical Conductors
Materials have an associated property called their electrical conductivity. It refers to how easily electricity flows through them. Materials that are good conductors, like copper, typically have free Electrons, which allow them to transfer charge easily.
A material which is good at conducting is called a conductor, and one which isn’t is called a insulator or dielectric.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 24-5

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Force
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Newtons Laws of Motion
Force
A force is essentially a push or pull.
By Newton’s Second Law of Motion, the acceleration of an object is based on its mass and the force being applied.
F_{net} = ma \to a = \frac{F_{net}}{m}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapters 3-5

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Friction
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Newtons Laws of Motion
Friction
Friction is a force that counteracts motion. There are three main types of friction.
Static Friction
The friction that must be overcome to start moving. Also referred to as the force of friction between two objects at rest relative to each other.
F_{s} \leq \mu_{s}\times F_{n}
Kinetic Friction
The force which counteracts an object from moving.
F_{k}=\mu_{k}\times F_{n}
Rolling Friction
The friction that occurs from an object not being perfectly round.
Car Tires
Car tires are generally thought of as being static friction, because a perfect circle rolling has only one point of contact, which is instantaneously at rest relative to the road.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Inertial Frames of Reference
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Inertial Frames of Reference
An inertial frame of reference is one where the velocity is constant. This means you can be moving, as long as you are not accelerating (that includes changing direction!)


                  
                  The Principle of Galilean Relativity 
                  
                

Newton’s Laws of Motion apply equally in any inertial frame of reference.



There is No Special Frame of Reference
All frames of reference are considered equal. It is perfectly valid for a cyclist traveling at a constant 20 mph to say that a passerby, who from their frame of reference isn’t moving, has a velocity of -20 mph.

References
Modern Physics; Chapter 1

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Internal and External Forces
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Linear Momentum
Internal and External Forces
When one object in a Physics System puts force on another object in a system, it is considered an internal force.
An external force is caused by an object outside the system.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Keplers Laws
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Keplers Laws
Kepler was a famous 16-17th century mathematician and astronomer, most notable for his discovery of 3 laws which govern the motion of planets.
1st Law


                  
                  Kepler's 1st 
                  
                

The planets move in elliptical orbits, with the sun as a focus.


2nd Law


                  
                  Kepler's 2nd 
                  
                

Planets cover equal area in equal times.



3rd Law


                  
                  Kepler's 3rd 
                  
                

A planet’s orbital period is proportional to the cube of its orbit.
T^{2} \propto r^{3}



References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:

Kinematic Equations
Constant Acceleration
x = x_{0}+v_{0}t+ \frac{1}{2}at^{2}
v=v_{0}+at
v_{\text{avg}}=\frac{v+v_{0}}{2}
v^{2}=v_{0}^{2}+ 2a(x -x_{0})

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Mass
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic:
Mass
Mass is a measure of the amount of matter in an object. It is distinct from Weight.
The SI unit for mass is the kilogram.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Collisions in Two Dimensions
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Linear Momentum
Collisions in Two Dimensions
Collisions in two dimensions are a little tricky because you need to know all four vector components to find the resulting vectors.
Special Case: Elastic Collision of Equal Mass
Suppose a 2-D elastic collision between equal mass objects, and that object B is at rest. The result of the collision is that the two objects (A + B) will move apart at right angles.
This is useful for billiard ball collisions.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Collisions
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Linear Momentum
Collisions
Collisions are interactions between two or more objects in a Physics System. Total momentum is conserved in all collisions. There are two types of collisions, classified as:
Elastic Collisions
Inelastic Collisions
Many real-life collisions are classified as being kinetic for simplicity sake, but they rarely are truly conservative.
Collisions in Two Dimensions

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Elastic Collisions
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Linear Momentum
Elastic Collisions
In an elastic collision, the total Kinetic Energy remains constant.
One Dimensional Elastic Collisions
The following equations allow you to determine the final speeds of two objects, a and b in an elastic collision, assuming that b is at rest at the start of the problem. You can manipulate your frame of reference in order to make this true.
V_{a}' = \left(\frac{m_{a}-m_{b}}{m_{a}+m_{b}}\right) V_{a}
V_{b}' = \left(\frac{2m_{a}}{m_{a}+m_{b}}\right)V_{a}
The speed of approach of the two objects is exactly equal to the speed of the separation of the two objects after the collision:
V_{b}' - V_{a}' = V_{a}
***

## References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Impulse
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Linear Momentum
Impulse
An impulse is the change in Linear Momentum.
\Delta \vec{P} = \vec{F}_{net avg} \Delta t
An impulse has units of \vec{J} or Newton seconds.
The impulse is the same for a large force acting over a short time or a small force acting over a large time.
In integral form:
\vec{J} = \int\limits_{t1 }^{t2}{(\vec{\textbf{F}}_{\text{ net external}})dt}

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Inelastic Collisions
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Linear Momentum
Inelastic Collisions
A collision in which the total Kinetic Energy does not remain constant. Note the special case of Perfectly Inelastic Collision, where the objects stick together.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Law of Conservation of Linear Momentum
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Law of Conservation of Linear Momentum
Topic: Linear Momentum


                  
                  Conservation of Linear Momentum 
                  
                

If the net external force acting on a system is zero, then the total linear momentum of the system is constant or conserved.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Linear Momentum
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Linear Momentum
\vec{P} = m\vec{v}
Note that momentum has a direction, unlike Kinetic Energy.
The rate of change of momentum is equal to the net force:
\sum\limits \vec{F} =  \frac{d\vec{P}}{dt}
This feels quite natural as if there is no net force there will be no change in momentum. The idea doesn’t really tell us anything new about single objects, but is instead useful for systems of objects.
Momentum is often conserved. Law of Conservation of Linear Momentum.
The units for momentum are just \frac{\text{ kg}\text{ m}}{\text{s}}. There isn’t a common name for this.

Perfectly Inelastic Collision
A collision in which the objects stick together. There is only one final velocity.
In order to solve these problems, you use the Law of Conservation of Linear Momentum.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Newtons Law of Gravity
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Newton’s Law of Gravity
Every mass in the universe attracts every other mass in the universe with a force that is directly proportional to the product of the two masses involved and is inversely proportional to the square of the distance separating them.
F_{g} = G\frac{m_{1} \times m_{2}}{r^{2}}
G equals the gravitational constant \dfrac{6.67 E^{-11} N * m}{kg^2}, the masses are measured in kilograms, and the distance is measured in meters.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:

Projectile Motion
Projectile motion is an application of the Kinematic Equations for constant acceleration when the only force of acceleration is gravity. In other words, the projectile object is in Free Fall.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Angular Motion
Rolling Motion
Rolling motion occurs when there is translational and angular motion.
For it to occur without slipping,
v_{cm} = R \omega
Where v_{cm} is the velocity of the center of mass, R is the radius of the rolling object, and \omega is the Angular Velocity.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Velocity
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Velocity
Velocity is a vector that denotes how fast and in what direction something is moving.
Mathematically, it is written as \vec{v} = \vec{x}/t
where \vec{x} represents the displacement.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Weight
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic:
Weight
The weight of an object is defined in two ways:

The mass of the object times the force of gravity: W = mg
The value measured on a scale

The issue with the second definition is that a scale will read different values if you are accelerating. I suppose that mg might be different too…
Unit
If W = mg, then the SI Units for weight are \text{ kg} \times \text{m/s}^{2}, which is called a Newton (N).

Concepts/Science/Physics/Optics/Index-of.title: Index of Refraction
Concepts/Science/Physics/Optics/Index-of.content:
Index of Refraction
A medium is a material through which light or some other wave passes.
Different transparent mediums have different optical densities, based on the speed of light in the material. For example, light travels faster in air than in glass.
Each transparent material is then assigned a value called an index of refraction. The greater the index, the slower that light travels. The symbol for the index of refraction is n, and the equation is:
n =\frac{c}{v}
Where n represents the index of refaction without a unit,
c represents the speed of light in a vacuum. This is a constant 3.00 E8 \frac{m}{s}.
v represents the speed of light in the specific material. The unit must agree with the unit for c.
Index of Refraction for Common Substances

































SubstanceIndex of Refractionair1.00ethyl alcohol1.36water1.33glass1.52ice1.31diamond2.42

Concepts/Science/Physics/Optics/Snells-L.title: Snells Law
Concepts/Science/Physics/Optics/Snells-L.content:
Snell’s Law
Snell’s Law allows use to predict the path of light as it travels from one medium to another. Many scientists tried to find a mathematical relationship for this, but the discovery came at the hand of Willebrord Snell, a Duth mathematician.
The Snell’s Law Equation
n_{1} \sin{\theta_{1}} = n_{2} \sin{\theta_{2}}
Where n_{1} is the index of refraction of the first medium, n_{2} is the second, \theta_{1} is the angle of incidence, in degrees, and \theta_{2} is the angle of refraction.
The following image shows these angles:

Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.title: Electrons
Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.content:
Electrons
Electrons are negatively charged subatomic particles that orbit the nuclei of Atoms. A single electron has one negative Elementary Charge, denoted -e.
Electrons form the basis of electricity, magnetism, and more. Additionally, they are fundamental to the field of Quantum Mechanics.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.title: Photons
Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.content:
Photons
Photons are a fundamental particle, like Electrons. They are bundles, or quanta, of light.
In certain experiments, it is observed that light behaves exactly like a wave. Such as Young’s Experiment with the double slits. Light also reflects, just like Waves.
However, certain other experiments with light show that light travels as photons in quanta, containing certain measurable amounts of energy. As a result, the nature of light is now called the wave-particle duality. It is accepted that light will behave as a wave under some conditions, and a particle under others. This a conundrum that is difficult to understand.
The energy of a photon is equal to the frequency times Planck’s constant: E = hf

Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.title: Planck Constant
Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.content:
Planck’s Constant
Planck’s constant, denoted by h, is a fundamental physical constant. A photon has energy equal to its Frequency multiplied by h.
In SI Units, it has the exact value h = 6.62607015 \times 10^{-34} \text{ J}\cdot \text{Hz}^{-1}.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.title: Quantum Mechanics
Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.content:
Quantum Mechanics


                  
                  Quantum Mechanics 
                  
                

The study of the behavior of nature at a scale below the atom.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.title: Strong Interaction
Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.content:
Strong Interaction
The Strong Interaction is a Fundamental Forces that confines Quarks into Protons, Neutrons, and other Hadrons. It also binds hadrons together, where it is called the nuclear force.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.title: Strong Nuclear Force
Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.content:
Strong Nuclear Force
The strong nuclear force acts between Hadrons, most commonly observed between the Protons and Neutrons in the Nucleus of Atoms. The nuclear force is strong enough to overcome the force caused by the Electrical Fields of like charges when protons are placed near each other, allowing for nuclei to bind together.
Note that this is NOT the Strong Interaction

Concepts/Science/Physics/Relativity/Eins.title: Einstein Notation
Concepts/Science/Physics/Relativity/Eins.content:
Topic: Tensors
Einstein Notation
In tensor math, you generalize by summing over a list of indices a lot, for example
\sum\limits_{i=1}^{3} a_{i}x_{i} = a_{1}x_{1} + a_{2}x_{2} + a_{3}x_{3}
Einstein notation is a shorthand for this:
\sum\limits_{i=1}^{3} a_{i}x_{i} \to a_{i}x_{i}
In this case, i is called a Dummy Index.
Rules

Any twice-repeated index in a single term is summed over.

a_{ij}b_{j} = a_{i1}b_{1} + a_{i2}b_{2} + a_{i2}b_{2}
You can replace a “dummy index” with anything that is not already in the expression and that is over the same range.


A Free Index is not summed over.
No index may occur 3 or more times in a given term.
In an equation involving Einstein notation, the free indices on both sides must match

x_{i} = a_{ij}b_{j} \quad \checkmark
A_{i} = B_{ij} \quad \times



Non-identities

a_{ij}(x_{i} + y_{i}) \neq a_{ij}x_{i} + a_{ij}y_{j}
If you expand it out, the left hand side has highest terms of i = 2 and j = 2, so both i and j are dummy indices. However in the right handside the left term has a free variable j and a dummy variable i, and the right has the inverse. These are inconsistent.
a_{ij}x_{i}y_{j} \neq a_{ij}x_{j}y_{i}
We have dummy indices on both sides, however the coefficients are different when you expand so these aren’t equal.

Identities

a_{ij}(x_{j} + y_{j}) = a_{ij}x_{j} + a_{ij}y_{j}
a_{ij}x_{i}y_{j} = a_{ij}y_{j}x_{i} - commutative multiplication
(a_{ij} + a_{ji})x_{i}x_{j} = 2a_{ij}x_{i}x_{j}


References
Einstein Summation Convention: an Introduction
Einstein Notation: Proofs, Examples, and Kronecker Delta

Concepts/Science/Physics/Relativity/Spec.title: Special Relativity
Concepts/Science/Physics/Relativity/Spec.content:
Topic: Laws of Physics
Special Relativity
Special relativity is the idea proposed by Einstein to solve the conundrum that the speed of light is constant regardless of your speed. It is the special case of General Relativity where both frames of reference are inertial.
The Conundrum
As described in Inertial Frames of Reference, there is no special frame of reference, and all laws of motion apply equally. However, we have observed that the speed of light is constant regardless of how you are moving. That is contradictory; if you are moving at the speed of light towards a flashlight, shouldn’t the light particles be traveling towards you at a speed of 2c?
Well, to solve that discrepancy, Einstein devised the idea of relativity; that time and space distort around an object, becoming more distorted as the object moves at a larger percentage of c.
A famous example of this is clocks. If you have three stationary clocks at different places, they will all see time in the same manner; after an hour has passed, all should show that an hour has passed. Now, take one of the clocks and let it move at 95% the speed of light. In the time in which the two stationary clocks observe 1 hour, the moving clock will only experience:
\Delta t' = \beta \Delta t = 1 hr\times \sqrt{1 - \frac{(0.95c)^{2}}{c^{2}}} \times \frac{60 \text{ minutes}}{1hr} = 18.7 \text{ minutes}
If you stopped the moving clock after that 1 hour, you would find that it read a dramatically different value from that of the two that were stationary the entire time.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Adiabatic Processes
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Adiabatic Processes
In an adiabatic process, no Heat flow occurs; typically due to very short time periods, or extremely well insulated systems.
Adiabatic Problem Solving
Q = 0, so by the First Law of Thermodynamics,
\Delta E_{\text{int}} = -W
It can also be derived that, if you let \gamma = \frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}} (see Molar Specific Heat),
PV^{\gamma} = \text{constant}
For an ideal diatomic gas at or near room temperature, \gamma is 1.4.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Boltzmann Constant
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Boltzmann Constant
The Boltzmann Constant, denoted k_{b}, is an extremely prevalent value in thermodynamics. It is used in the Ideal Gas Law, quantifying Entropy, and Thermal Radiation. It is given the value
k_{b} = \frac{R}{N_{A}} = 1.38 \times 10^{-23}  \text{ J/K}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19; 20

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Calorimetry
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Calorimetry
Calorimetry is the techniques used to solve for the temperature or energy required to change the temperature of a substance. It involves Heat and Latent Heat. A calorimeter attempts to isolate the system, so that no mass or energy flows into or out. Most problems rely on the assumption that the system is isolated, such that
\sum\limits Q =0


                  
                  What is the final temperature of the system?
                  
                

200 cubic centimeters of tea at 95 degrees Celsius are poured into a 150 gram cup at 25 degrees Celsius. What will be the common final temperature T of the tea and cup when equilibrium is reached? Assume the system is isolated.
We assume that tea is approximately water. 1 cc of water is 1 gram, so we have 200 grams of water at 95 degrees Celsius. The specific heat of water is c_{w}. The specific heat of glass is c_{g} and there are 150 grams.
\begin{aligned} \sum\limits Q &= 0\\ 0 &= m_{w}c_{w}(T-T_{tea}) + m_{c}c_{c}(T-T_{cup})\\ 0 &= m_{w}c_{w}T - m_{w}c_{w}T_{tea} + m_{c}c_{c}T - m_{c}c_{c}T_{cup}\\ m_{w}c_{w}T + m_{c}c_{c}T &= m_{w}c_{w}T_{tea} + m_{c}c_{c}T_{cup}\\ T &= \frac{m_{w}c_{w}T_{tea} + m_{c}c_{c}T_{cup}}{m_{w}c_{w} + m_{c}c_{c}}\end{aligned}
Then you simply substitute.



References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Carnot Engine
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Carnot Engine
The Carnot Engine, pioneered by a French general in Napelon’s army, is an idealized reversible engine that would be optimally efficient.
The cycle of the engine goes like this:
flowchart TD

A[Isovolumetric Expansion] --> B[Adiabatic Expansion] --> C[Isothermal Compression] --> D[Adiabatic Compression] --> A

Restrictions
A Carnot Engine must, by definition, be reversible. That means each leg must be reversible. However, Friction is non-reversible, so a Carnot Engine assumes no friction. Obviously this is an idealized model.
Efficiency
In a Carnot Engine, the efficiency is
\frac{Q_{L}}{Q_{H}} = \frac{T_{L}}{T_{H}} \to e_\text{max} = 1 - \frac{T_{L}}{T_{H}}
This can actually be generalized to say that ALL Heat Engines are bounded in efficiency by the temperature high and low of their cycle.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 20

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Coefficient of Performance
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Coefficient of Performance
The coefficient of performance is closely related to the Heat Efficiency of a heat engine. The coefficient of performance instead describes the “efficiency” of a fridge, AC, heat pump, or minisplit. These are essentially heat engines in reverse; you use work (electricity) to extract heat from a colder environment.
For a fridge/AC, the coefficient of performance is
CoP = \frac{Q_{L}}{W}  = \frac{Q_{L}}{Q_{H}-Q_{L}}
and the ideal situation gives
CoP_\text{max} = \frac{T_{L}}{T_{H}-T_{L}}
For a heat pump, it is instead
CoP = \frac{Q_{H}}{W} = \frac{Q_{H}}{Q_{H}-Q_{L}}; \quad CoP_\text{max} = \frac{T_{H}}{T_{H}-T_{L}}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 20’

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Entropy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Entropy
Entropy is a measure of disorder. It is a state variable. It is given the symbol S and measured in Joules per Kelvin.
Changes in Entropy
We approximate that, at the same Temperature, a change in entropy is given by
\Delta S = \frac{Q}{T}
This gives us the very important fact that when heat flows from hot to cold, as described by the Second Law of Thermodynamics, entropy increases. One way to conceptualize this is that a small change in an already very disorderly situation has less of an effect than a small change in a very orderly system. This change in entropy formula is more accurately stated as
dS = \frac{dQ}{T}
Quantifying Entropy
It is far easier to calculate a change in entropy than to give an exact value. However, it is a state variable, so a given state must have some exact amount of entropy. To calculate this, we first consider the idea of macro and microstates. A macrostate is a combination of state variables, including pressure, temperature, volume, and entropy. A microstate is one possible way in which a system of particles and arrange themselves to get a specific macrostate. It turns out that this number is enormous. If you denote the number of microstates as \Omega, then Boltzmann found that entropy is
S = k_{b} \ln{\Omega}
where k_{b} is the Boltzmann Constant.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 20

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Equipartition of Energy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Equipartition of Energy
The theory of the equipartition of energy states that each Degree of Freedom of an Ideal Gas equally contains approximately \frac{1}{2}kT energy. A monoatomic gas therefore has an Internal Energy of \frac{3}{2}kT, because it only has translational modes. Now you would assume that diatomic gas might have 6 degrees of freedom, 3 translational and 3 rotational, but one of the rotational axes has such a small moment of inertia that it is ignored. There is also the vibrational modes, but these are only active above roughly 1000 Kelvin. Therefore, a diatomic gas generally has
E_\text{int} = \frac{5}{2}kT = \frac{5}{2} nRT
of internal energy. This is the value generally used for air.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: First Law of Thermodynamics
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
First Law of Thermodynamics
The first law of thermodynamics states that, for a closed system,
\Delta E_{\text{int}} = Q - W
where E_\text{int} is the Internal Energy of a system, Q is the Heat flow into the system, and W is the Work done by the system. Note the sign convention.  

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Gas Laws
Heat Efficiency
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Heat Efficiency
In a Heat Engine, there is a concept called efficiency. It reflects how much Work you get out for a certain amount of Heat input:
\text{Efficiency} = e = \frac{\text{what you get out}}{\text{what you put in}} = \frac{W}{Q_{H}}
In a heat engine, W = Q_{H} - Q_{L}, so
e = \frac{Q_{H}-Q_{L}}{Q_{H}} = 1 - \frac{Q_{L}}{Q_{H}}
There is a related concept called the Coefficient of Performance for cooling objects like fridges and air conditioners.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 20

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Heat Engines
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Heat Engines
Heat engines are objects which take in heat and produce work.

Topic: Thermodynamics

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Heat
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Heat
Heat is the amount of thermal energy flowing from one substance to another. It is the energy that transfers from one object to another because of a temperature difference. Matter contains several forms of energy, but it does not contain heat. Instead, heat is energy in transit moving from a body of higher temperature to a body of lower temperature. Once the heat is transferred, the energy is no longer considered to be heat.
Transclude of Thermal-Equilibrium
Heat Transfer
To calculate the quantity of heat transfer related to a temperature change of a substance, use this equation:
Q = mc\Delta T
Where Q = the quantity of heat, measured in Joules (J)
m is the Mass of the substance, measured in Kilograms (kg)
c is the Specific Heat capacity of the substance, measured in \frac{J}{kg*C \degree}
\Delta T is the change in temperature of the substance, measured in C \degree
Transclude of Latent-Heat

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Internal Energy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Internal Energy
A Physics System has an inherent amount of Energy, which arises from the molecular motion of matter. The amount is represented by U or E_\text{int}, and is measured in Joules. The change in internal energy of a closed system is represented in the First Law of Thermodynamics.
For an Ideal Gas, the change is calculated as
\Delta E_{\text{int}} = n C_{v} \Delta T

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Isobaric Processes
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Isobaric Processes
Iso = same, baric = pressure. This is a Thermodynamic Processes in which the Pressure is kept constant. We assume the Mass also stays constant.
An isobaric PV diagram

Isobaric Problem Solving
In an isobaric process, the Work is
W = P\Delta V

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Isothermal Processes
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Isothermal Processes
Iso = same, thermal = Temperature. This is a Thermodynamic Processes in which the temperature is kept constant. We assume the Mass also stays constant.
The following image shows a pressure-volume diagram for an isothermal process.

Isothermal Problem Solving
In an ideal gas, the internal energy only depends on the temperature. Since the temperature remains constant, we know that, by the First Law of Thermodynamics,
E_\text{int} = Q - W = 0 \to \boxed{Q = W}
It can also be found, using the integral in Work In Volume Changes that the work done in isothermically going from volume A to volume B is
W = nRT \ln{\left(\frac{V_{b}}{V_{a}}\right)}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Isovolumetric Processes
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Isovolumetric Processes
Iso = same, volumetric = volume. This is a Thermodynamic Processes in which the volume is kept constant. We assume the Mass also stays constant.
PV diagram

Isovolumetric Problem Solving
If the volume remains constant, than the work done on the system is 0, so
\Delta E_{\text{int}} = Q

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Latent Heat
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Latent Heat
The latent heat of fusion is defined as the amount of Heat one unit Mass of material, at its melting point, must absorb to change from the solid phase to the liquid phase with no change in temperature. See Phase Changes. The latent heat of vaporization is the same for boiling.
If you are trying to calculate the heat transfer related to a phase change, use the equation below:
Q=m \cdot H_f||H_v
where Q is the quantity of heat in J, m is the mass in kg, and H_f is the latent heat of fusion or H_v is the latent heat of vaporization

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Laws of Thermodynamics
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Laws of Thermodynamics
The Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics
There is no net flow of heat between two systems in thermal contact that have the same temperature.
The First Law of Thermodynamics
In a closed system, the total amount of heat energy added to a system is equal to the increase in the internal energy of the system plus the work done by the system.
Q = W + \Delta U
where Q = the heat added,
W = the work done,
U = the internal energy of an object.
See First Law of Thermodynamics.
Sample Problem


                  
                  Sample First Law of Thermodynamics Problem 
                  
                

While playing tennis, Joan does 5.5 E7 J of work and gives off 2.3 E7 J of heat. What is the change in Joan’s internal energy?
Q = -2.3 E7 J; negative because it is given off to the environment
W = 5.5 E7 J; positive because the work is done on the environment
\Delta U = ? = Q - W = (-2.3 E7 J) - (5.5 E7 J) = -7.8 E7 J


The Second Law of Thermodynamics
Heat itself never flows from a cold object to a hot object. Second Law of Thermodynamics.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Linear Expansion
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Linear Expansion
Materials change in size when they heat up or cool off; they expand or contract. Generally, a material expands when Temperature rises. The amount of expansion per Celsius (or Kelvin) degree is an intrinsic property of a substance. This property is called the coefficient of linear expansion (\alpha).
The equation for calculating how much a substance will increase linearly with a change in temperature is shown below:
\Delta L = \alpha L_{0} \cdot \Delta T
where \Delta L is the change in length, \alpha is the coefficient of linear expansion, L_0 is the original length, and \Delta T is the change in temperature.
An alternative form is given by
\ell = \ell_{0}(1 + \alpha \Delta T)

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Molar Specific Heat
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Molar Specific Heat
The Specific Heat of a Ideal Gas depends on the type of process in which the Temperature is being changed. This is because during an Isovolumetric Processes no work is being done to expand the container, so all heat flow goes into raising the temperature, while in an Isobaric Processes some energy must be spent to do work to expand, so not all energy increases temperature.
Constant Volume: Q = nC_{v} \Delta T
Constant Pressure: Q = nC_{p} \Delta T
Interestingly, a result can be found that shows that the relationship between C_{v} and C_{p} is almost exactly the Universal Gas Constant.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Second Law of Thermodynamics
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Second Law of Thermodynamics
The second law of thermodynamics can be stated in many ways. First, note that Entropy (S) is disorder.

In any natural process, \Delta S \geq 0
Heat naturally or spontaneously flows from hot to cold
There is no such thing as a perfect Heat Engines; you can’t have 100% Heat Efficiency.

While these distinct definitions may seem disconnected, they can be all explained to mean the same thing using PV diagrams and a bit of trickery.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 20

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Specific Heat
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Specific Heat
The specific heat of a material specifies how much Energy is required to raise a kilogram of the material by one degree Celsius. Each material has a different value, and these values change ever-so-slightly with temperature.
Transclude of Molar-Specific-Heat#molar-specific-heat

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Temperature
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Temperature
The temperature of a sample of Matter is a measure of the average Kinetic Energy of the Molecules that make up that sample.
In everyday speech, Heat and temperature are related, but they are scientifically subtly different. Heat is an amount of Thermal Energy, whereas temperature is a property of a sample.
Nearly all matter expands when its temperature increases, and contracts when its temperature decreases. A common thermometer measures temperature by using a liquid that expands or contracts, like mercury. This phenomenon is called Linear Expansion.
Temperature is an Intensive Property. It is measured by the SI unit known as the Kelvin.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Thermal Conduction
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Thermal Conduction
Two materials in contact with one another have a tendency to transfer Heat. On a molecular level, this occurs because the hotter object (or part of an object) has more molecular motion than the cold. When the molecules in the hot air vibrate more quickly, they will collide more often with the cooler ones, transferring energy, which propagates through the medium. Metals are good at this process because of free Electrons, which is also why they are good Electrical Conductors.
It is experimentally found that the heat flow Q over a time interval t is given by
\frac{Q}{t} = kA \frac{T_{1}-T_{2}}{\ell}
where k is a constant of thermal conductivity (in units J/(s * m * K)), A is the cross-sectional area of the material, \ell is the thickness of the material, and T_{1}, T_{2} are the temperatures.
You often see this represented in differential terms, with a temperature gradient:
\frac{dQ}{dt} = -kA \frac{dT}{dx}
Thermal Constant
Materials with high thermal conductivity are said to be good conductors. Those with low values are said to be good insulators.
R-Values
Typically measured in Imperial units, a materials R-value measures how good of a insulator it is.
R = \frac{\ell}{k}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Thermal Convection
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Thermal Convection
Convection is the process whereby heat flows due to the bulk movement of molecules from one location to another inside a Fluids.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Thermal Equilibrium
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Thermal Equilibrium
When heat spontaneously flows from a warmer substance to a cooler one and the objects reach the same temperature, we say that the objects have reached thermal equilibrium.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Thermal Radiation
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Thermal Radiation
Objects are said to radiate heat, which is the result of the emission of Electromagnetic Waves. The rate at which an object radiates heat has been found to be proportional to the fourth power of the Kelvin temperature, T. The rate of Heat Flow is given by the equation
\frac{Q}{t} = \epsilon \sigma AT^{4}
where \epsilon = [0, 1] is the emissivity of the material, \sigma is the Sigmund-Boltzmann Constant, \sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \text{W/m}^{2} \cdot \text{K}^{4}, and A is the surface area of the emitting object.
Objects with a high emissivity are found to also have a high rate of absorption; that is, a good emitter is a good absorber.  

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Thermodynamics
Thermodynamics is the branch of physics which handles Heat, Work, and Temperature. It is described by 3 Laws:

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Ultraviolet Catastrophe
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Ultraviolet Catastrophe
In the study of radiation, classical theory predicted that the energy of radiation caused by vibration could be of any energy. This idea, however, predicted that an ideal emitter would have emit an unbounded amount of energy, which obviously could not be true.
The ultraviolet catastrophe caused much upheaval in classical physics, but was ultimately resolved by Planck’s discovery that energy is discrete. Planck stated that radiation could only have values of hf, where f is the frequency and h is the eponymous Planck’s constant, h = 6.64 \times 10^{-34} \text{ J/s}.
While Planck discovered this idea, he did not have strong justification for it. It was Albert Einstein who explained the discreteness by proposing what was later named the photon, at least according to Professor Robert Bragdon.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Work In Volume Changes
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Work In Volume Changes
When the volume of an Ideal Gas changes, it must do some amount of Work to expand. This amount is given by
W = \int\limits_{V_{a}}^{V_{b}}{PdV}
where W is the Work in Joules, V_{a} and V_{b} are the starting and ending volumes, and P is the Pressure of the gas. This idea is very important for the First Law of Thermodynamics and the Thermodynamic Processes.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/De-Brogli.title: De Broglie Wavelength
Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/De-Brogli.content:
De Broglie Wavelength
French physicist Louis de Broglie postulated that every particle of matter is endowed with a wave to guide it as it travels. All bodies have a wavelength that is related to the body’s momentum, and given by the equation
\lambda = \frac{h}{p}
where \lambda is the wavelength, h is the physical constant called Planck’s Constant, and p is the Linear Momentum

Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/Doppler-E.title: Doppler Equation

Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/Longitudi.title: Longitudinal Waves
Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/Longitudi.content:
Longitudinal Waves

longitudinal waves move parallel to the direction of the wave

an example is Sound Waves in air. The molecules push each other forward and then bounce back, creating pockets of expansion (rarefaction) and compression.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/SHM/Dampe.title: Damped Harmonic Motion
Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/SHM/Dampe.content:
Topic: SHM
Damped Harmonic Motion
A damping force is one which impedes the oscillations of Simple Harmonic Motion, such as friction or air drag. The basic equation which describes the forces in such a case is
ma = -F - bv
Mass on a Spring
ma = -kx - bv \to \frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}} + \frac{b}{m} \frac{dx}{dt} + \frac{k}{m}x = 0
It turns out that the solution to this is
x(t) = Ae^{-\gamma t}\cos{(\omega' t + \phi)}
if:
\gamma = \frac{b}{2m} \quad \text{and} \quad \omega' = \sqrt{\frac{k}{m} - \frac{b^{2}}{4m^{2}}}
If \frac{b^{2}}{4m^{2}} is equal to 4mk, then there are no vibrations and the motion returns to equilibrium in the shortest time possible. This is known as critical damping.
If \frac{b^{2}}{4m^{2}} is instead less than 4mk, the system is under-damped and there will be oscillations.
If \frac{b^{2}}{4m^{2}} is greater than 4mk, the system is over-damped, and there will not be oscillations but it will not return to equilibrium in the fastest time.
Solution Proof
We have the equation m\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}  + \beta \frac{dx}{dt} + k x = 0 from the above physics. We introduce that \lambda = \frac{\beta}{2m} and \omega^{2} = \frac{k}{m}, yielding \frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}} + 2 \lambda \frac{dx}{dt} + \omega^{2} x. By the technique in Solutions of Homogeneous Linear Equations with Constant Coefficients, we have m_{1} = - \lambda + \sqrt{\lambda^{2} - \omega^{2}}, \quad m_{2} = -\lambda - \sqrt{\lambda^{2} - \omega^{2}}
The sign of this discriminant gives us the cases above:

if \lambda^{2} - \omega^{2} > 0, it is overdamped: x(t) = e^{-\lambda t}(c_{1} e^{\sqrt{\lambda^{2} - \omega^{2}}t}) + c_{2}e^{- \sqrt{\lambda^{2} - \omega^{2}}t}
\lambda^{2} - \omega^{2} = 0 is critically damped: x(t) = e^{-\lambda t}(c_{1} + c_{2}t)
\lambda^{2} - \omega^{2} < 0 gives complex roots and it is underdamped: x(t) = e^{-\lambda t}(c_{1} \cos{(\sqrt{\omega^{2} - \lambda^{2}}t)} + c_{2} \sin{(\sqrt{\omega^{2} - \lambda^{2}}t)})

Simple Pendulum with Damping
\frac{d^{2}\theta}{dt^{2}} + \frac{b}{\ell} \frac{d\theta}{dt} + \frac{g}{\ell}\theta = 0
Solution:
\theta = Ae^{-\gamma t} \cos{(\omega' t + \phi)}
when
\gamma = \frac{b}{2\ell} \quad \text{and} \quad \omega' = \sqrt{\frac{g}{\ell} - \frac{b^{2}}{4\ell^{2}}}

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/SHM/Mass-.title: Mass On A Spring
Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/SHM/Mass-.content:
Topic: SHM
Mass On A Spring
A mass on a spring is one of the most quintessential examples of Simple Harmonic Motion, and involves a system with a Mass suspended on the very end of a spring. Hang this vertically and pull down, and the spring will oscillate above and below the equilibrium position in Simple Harmonic Motion. The position, or height, as a function of time, can be described as
y = A \cos{(\omega t + \phi)}
where A is the amplitude, or the amount you initially pulled it by,
\omega is the angular frequency, which must equal \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}, and \phi is the phase shift; for example if you didn’t release the spring at t=0.
This solution can be found by solving (or proved by substitution) the equation \frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}} + \frac{k}{m}x = 0
which comes from:
ma = \sum\limits F \to m \frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}} = -kx
where k is the Spring Constant and F = -kx comes from Hooke’s Law.
Don’t forget about the more complex Damped Harmonic Motion.
Solving the Differential Equation
By Hooke’s Law we have a force acting opposite to Newtons Law of Gravity. The spring exerts a force of F = -ks where s is the elongation and k is the spring constant. A mass m is affixed to the bottom of the spring, causing it to reach an equilibrium position when mg = ks.
When a initial displacement is given (or an initial velocity), the system starts to vibrate. We denote x(t) as the displacement. The sum of all the forces is equal to ma (see Newtons Laws of Motion): \sum\limits F = m a = m \frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}} = mg - k(x + s) = mg -ks - kx = -kx
Rearranging, we have that m \frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}} + kx = 0
Or, as it is more often written, \frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}} + \omega^{2} x=0where \omega = \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}. By the technique outlined in Solutions of Homogeneous Linear Equations with Constant Coefficients, we can find that \lambda = \pm i \omega \Longrightarrow x(t) = c_{1} \cos{(\omega t)} + c_{2} \sin{(\omega t)}
This is also written as x(t) = A \sin{( \omega t + \phi)}
where A = \sqrt{c_{1}^{2} + c_{2}^{2}} and \phi = \arctan{(\frac{c_{1}}{c_{2}})}, as determined by the initial conditions. (or a similarly shifted cosine function, x(t) = A \cos{(\omega t - \phi)}).


                  
                  Example: Finding the Equation of Motion 
                  
                

A force of 400 Newtons stretches a spring 2 meters. A mass of 50 kilograms is attached to the end of the spring, and it is initially released from the equilibrium position with an upward velocity of 10 m/s. Find the equation of motion.
Solution:
First, we identify the given condition that x'(0) = 10 \text{ m/s}. The spring constant is F = kx \to k = \frac{F}{x} = \frac{400 \text{ N}}{2 \text{ m}} =200 \text{ N/m}. The equation of motion is \sum\limits F = ma = mg - k(x - s) = mg - kx - ks = -kx
which yields ma + kx = 0, where a = \frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}. If we let \omega = \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}} = 2 \text{ rad/s}, then we have the differential equation x'' + \omega^{2} x = 0.
To solve this, we let x = e^{\lambda t}, such that x'' = \lambda^{2} e^{\lambda t}. The system then becomes \lambda^{2} + \omega^{2} = 0, so \lambda = \pm i \omega. The general solution to the system is then x(t) = c_{1}e^{2i  t} + c_{2}e^{-2i t} = c_{1}' \cos{(2 t)} + c_{2}' \sin{(2 t)}
Now, we apply the condition that x'(0) = -2 c_{1} \sin{(0)} + 2c_{2} \cos{(0)} = 2c_{2} = -10 \to c_{2} = -5. Therefore, the final equation of motion is \boxed{x(t) = -5 \sin{(2t)}}



References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 14

Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/SHM/Physi.title: Physical Pendulum
Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/SHM/Physi.content:
Topic: Simple Harmonic Motion
Physical Pendulum
A physical pendulum is a pendulum where the mass is distributed, not concentrated at the end as with a ball on string (Simple Pendulum). A physical pendulum experiences torque equal to
\tau = -mgh \sin{(\theta)} \approx -mgh\theta
where m is the mass, g is the acceleration due to gravity, h is the distance along the object from the pivot point to the center of mass, and \theta is the angle from the vertical. We can use the Small-Angle Approximation to estimate that the torque is linear.
I\alpha = \tau \to I \frac{d^{2}\theta}{dt^{2}} = -mgh\theta
\frac{d^{2}\theta}{dt^{2}} + \frac{mgh}{I}\theta = 0
The solution to this Differential Equation is
\theta(t) = \theta_\text{max} \cos{(\omega t + \phi)}
when \omega = \sqrt{\frac{mgh}{I}}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 14

Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/SHM/Reson.title: Resonance

Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/SHM/Simpl.title: Simple Harmonic Motion
Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/SHM/Simpl.content:
Simple Harmonic Motion
Simple harmonic motion relies on two key facts:

Must have some equilibrium position
If disturbed, experiences a linear restoring force which acts to return the system to equilibrium

The most basic equation for simple harmonic motion is
x(t) = A \cos{(\omega t + \phi)}
where A is the amplitude, \omega is the Angular Frequency, and \phi is the angular offset or phase.
The maximum acceleration is A\omega^{2}.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/SHM/Simpl.title: Simple Pendulum
Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/SHM/Simpl.content:
Topic: SHM
Simple Pendulum
A simple pendulum is a system consisting of a rod of length \ell, at the end of which all mass is concentrated. An example is a very thin string, such that its mass is negligible, with a very dense metal ball at the end.
If disturbed, the pendulum will try to come to rest, but endlessly cycle back and forth in Simple Harmonic Motion. Without damping, the equation describing the position is:
x(t) = A \cos{(\omega t + \phi)}
when \omega = \sqrt{\frac{g}{\ell}}. This implies that the period of the pendulum does not rely on the mass. The solution also relies on the Small-Angle Approximation.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 14

Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/Transvers.title: Transverse Waves
Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/Transvers.content:
Transverse Waves

particles move perpendicular to the wave’s direction

Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/Wave-Inte.title: Wave Intensity

Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/Waves.title: Waves
Concepts/Science/Physics/Waves/Waves.content:
Waves
Waves are disturbances that move, carrying energy but not matter. They come in many, many forms, including light waves, ocean waves, Sound Waves, and Electromagnetic Radiation.
There are two primary categories of waves, although there is overlap within them:

Transverse Waves
Longitudinal Waves

When graphed, a wave alternates between high points, called crests, and low points, called troughs in a rhythmic pattern. The most basic graphs of this form are \sin{(x)} and \cos{(x)}, which both have a crest of 1 and trough of -1.
Properties
The most basic properties of waves are:

Amplitude: typically denoted as A, a measure of how far the wave goes from equilibrium to reach either crest or trough.
Period: denoted T, the time it takes for the wave to complete one full cycle
Frequency: denoted f or F, the number of cycles which a wave completes in one second; inversely related to period
Angular Frequency: denoted \omega, the amount of times it completes a cycle of 2 \pi radians in a second; \omega = 2\pi f
Wavelength: typically denoted \lambda, the distance between two successive points, e.g. crest to crest
Velocity: v = \lambda f


References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 15

KiCad.title: KiCad
KiCad.content:
KiCad
KiCad is an open-source suite for designing Printed Circuit Boards.

Printed-Circuit-Boards.title: Printed Circuit Boards
Printed-Circuit-Boards.content:
Printed Circuit Boards
A printed circuit board, or PCB, is a object that allows us to physically wire together, or route, the components of a Circuit. Typically, it consists of a plastic outer layer that sandwiches a copper conductive layer. The copper has traces that run from component to component and electrically connects them. Then, electrical components are fixed to conductive pads on the outer layers by Soldering.

Research/Ergonomic-Mechanical-Keyboards/.title: Ergonomic Keyboards
Research/Ergonomic-Mechanical-Keyboards/.content:
Ergonomic Keyboards
An ergonomic keyboard is a tool for inputting symbols to a computer in a way that doesn’t compromise on the user’s comfort. Typical features that might make a keyboard more ergonomic that the traditional counterpart are a split design, ortholinear or columnar staggered keys, or non-traditional angles.
I’ve spent a lot of time studying, building, using ergonomic keyboards. A tiny subset of my journey in this realm is documented in posts like

ErgoTravel
Dactyl Manuform R-Track
Icarus
Silvis
Tantalus

Soldering.title: Soldering
Soldering.content:
Soldering
Soldering is the process of connecting a component to a PCB by melting solder between the surfaces.
Traditionally, soldering is done using a soldering iron - essentially a very hot stick of metal that you gently touch to heat the circuit board, solder, and component together.
In more sophisticated designs, you may see solder paste, hot air guns, and reflow ovens used. By cutting out the manual element of the soldering iron, these techniques allow for much smaller packages on the components. Additionally, solder paste and reflow ovens scale much better for large scale assembly.

index.title: Introduction
index.content:
Hello, World!
Hey there! I am Eben Quenneville, a Physics student at the University of New Hampshire. This is a publicly accessible sub-section of my personal notes network built using Obsidian. I published it using Quartz, an awesome static website generator for Markdown notes.
This website is meant to be an easy place for me to publish anything I’ve been thinking about and think others might be too.
In the future, I plan to upload useful notes about classes I’ve taken and projects I’ve done. This will be for my own reference and anyone else stumbling through.
